question_text: According to kinetic theory, which quantity is directly proportional to the average kinetic energy of gas molecules?
explanation: Average kinetic energy is directly proportional to absolute (Kelvin) temperature.

question_text: What does the equation E<sub>k</sub> = (3/2)kT represent?
explanation: It gives the average kinetic energy per gas molecule as a function of absolute temperature.

question_text: Which assumption is made in the kinetic theory of ideal gases?
option_d: Time of collisions is negligible compared to time between collisions
explanation: This simplifies calculations and is valid for ideal gases at low pressure.

question_text: Which of the following is NOT an assumption of the kinetic theory of ideal gases?
option_a: Gas particles are in constant random motion
option_b: Gas particles exert forces on each other
option_d: Volume of individual gas particles is negligible
explanation: Ideal gas theory assumes no intermolecular forces between particles.

question_text: Which statement about the root mean square (rms) speed of gas molecules is correct?
option_b: It is constant for all gases
option_c: It increases with the square root of temperature
option_d: It is independent of molecular mass
explanation: v<sub>rms</sub> ∝ √T, so it increases as temperature increases.

question_text: Calculate the average kinetic energy of a gas molecule at 400 K. (k = 1.38×10⁻²³ J/K)
What happens to the pressure of a gas if the temperature doubles at constant volume?
explanation: From kinetic theory and the ideal gas law, P ∝ T when volume is constant.

question_text: Which best describes the motion of gas particles in an ideal gas?
option_c: They move randomly in straight lines until colliding
option_d: They move slowly due to intermolecular forces
explanation: Ideal gas particles move in random straight-line motion, with elastic collisions.

question_text: Why does pressure increase when gas temperature increases at constant volume?
option_c: Particles collide more frequently and with more force
explanation: Higher temperature means more kinetic energy, causing more frequent and forceful collisions.
